Actually, I hate cops. I can honestly say "hate" and mean it. But this 
looks to me like possibly the cop did a bar patron a favor by allowing him 
to walk home and securing his car, rather than taking the opportunity to 
hook someone up for DWI. The vehicle owner would appear to have shaken his 
hand for giving him a break, real or perceived, instead of fucking with 
him. He also then approached you in a pretty non threatening manner and 
didn't attempt to coerce you to identify yourself, as most cops would. He 
just took a photo and left without further interaction. I would expect that 
like any other cop, he's a power tripping dickhead, but at least during 
this encounter I don't really see much amiss. I'd actually have to say he 
acted with some modicum of restraint, which should be expected.﻿
You been marked watch out﻿

The cop took a picture of the photographer specifically because the 
photographer was engaging in constitutionally protected activity.  Imagine 
if the officer did that to a gay couple ?
Why is it okay for police to target photographers for harassment ?﻿

+Daniel Litchfield
 So, what about the general public in the street who could have seen his

open.

+xXSgtWolfXx I agree 100%, probably took the photo as a record just in case 
the the camera guy damages the car.. oh and I'm sure the guy who owns the 
car appreciated the invasion of his privacy be putting his tag and business 
on the Internet.

+Onus News Service Well the police officer was engaging in a 
constitutionally protected activity as well. He's free to take pictures of 
anyone he pleases just as anyone else. Why do you get mad when the cop does 
it but not the douchebag behind the camera? You're pretty dumb.

+Joseph Smith I have been an Officer since 2008. I love the job but I am 
ready to hang it up. To many people out there that want Officers dead. I 
have a family to watch and care of. I work for LUPD now and as soon as I am 
done with college I am done. God bless stay safe. May peace be with us and 
you.

+Luciano Freitas I hate to break it to you, but you are the minority. If 
what you say is actually true, that is.

+Joseph Smith Joseph I am a Police Officer and I serve the public, my duty 
is to protect and serve, but I have the duty to protect myself also from 
ignorant people. Just like there is bad cops there is bad people trying to 
hurt good cops. You are saying that we are getting rich. Man I can hardly 
pay my bills. I do this job like many other Officers out there do for the 
pleasure of putting a smile on somebodies face. If I wanted to get rich I 
would be a criminal and sell drugs. Peace be with us and the public.
+Joseph Smith yep, sounds like we'd agree :)

+gobbly1337 it would appear to be a simple miscommunication on both our 
parts. I wasn't meaning to imply that I can tell a cop what you do because 
"I pay your salary!" I was just trying to say that they are here for us, 
yet they seem to have abandoned us in order to get rich. Like every other 
problem we have right now, it all comes down to money.

+Joseph Smith What I replied to was the statement:

"They are also considered public servants. Meaning that the people are 
their boss, not the other way around."

Perhaps I suck at communication, perhaps yours is poor.  Either way, if you 
weren't implying that people were the bosses of police then I really don't 
have an issue.  I had no interest in arguing the purpose of the police with 
you, especially when I agree with you, lol.  I think it would be nice if 
police actually were compelled to protect and serve.  I purely replied and 
took issue to the perceived statement about people being the bosses of 
police, and the whole "I pay your salary" mentality.  If I misunderstood 
you, and you mean to convey something else, then my bad.

+gobbly1337 again, you're side stepping my point and focusing on a single 
word to justify your perceived superior opinion. Saying I'm the cops boss 
was never to be an analogy of the relationship between officer and 
civilian. You saw it as me saying the cups have to do whatever I say, and 
that's incorrect. They are paid with taxes corrected from the people, 
meaning technically you write their paychecks. As I said before, they are 
here to serve and protect the people. Meaning the in a true democracy, 
people dictate how they operate and not the other way around.

+Joseph Smith And nothing you says would justify you being a policeman's 
boss.  Talk all the trash you want about cops, point out all the injustice. 
 I'm right there with you on it all, rallying against abuse of authority. 
 None of this have I taken issue with.  I was very clear and concise, and 
you have talked about all sorts of things, none of which justify your 
position that the public are the bosses of police.  the police have a very 
clear mandate in their profession.  Shame on those who violate that, but 
none of it means anyone but their actual boss is their boss.

+gobbly1337 as with most statists, you fail to see the point by focusing on 
a single word in a sentence and taking it out of context. The motto of the 
police department is "to protect and serve" yet the only people they seem 
to be serving are themselves. They are supposed to help us when we are in 
trouble, and protect us from harm. Who are they serving and protecting when 
they taser a 9 year old girl? Who are they serving and protecting when they 
best a homeless man to death with no provocation? Who are they serving and 
protecting when they toss a flash bang grenade into a babies crib? They are 
nothing but a gang hiding behind a badge and using their perceived 
"authority" to bully the general public into submission. "Do as you're told 
or get beat."

But you want to argue that it makes you their boss?  You have illustrated 
why comparing your relationship to police and business structure is 
insincere.  Which was also my point.

+gobbly1337 so getting pulled over for no reason, having conflict initiated 
against my will, and then being forced to give up protection money makes me 
a customer?

o_O  you realize that they are also public citizens?  Can they just do what 
they want and claim that they are their own boss?  Their boss is their 
superior officer.  You are a customer.  Not by choice, but if you want an 
analogy to business that is the closest it gets.

They are also considered public servants. Meaning that the people are their 
boss, not the other way around.
